{{Infobox airport | name =NAAS Chincoteague | ensign = | ensign_size = | ensign_alt = | nativename = | nativename-a = | nativename-r = | image =NAAS Chincoteague VA NAN9-48.jpg | image-width = <!-- if less than 200 --> | image_alt = | caption =Aerial view of NAAS Chincoteague in the mid-1940s | image2 = | image2-width = <!-- if less than 200 --> | image2_alt = | caption2 = | IATA = | ICAO = | FAA = | TC = | LID = | GPS = | WMO = | type = | owner-oper = | owner = | operator =[[United States Navy]] (transferred to NASA) | city-served = | location = | opened = <!-- {{start date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | closed = <!-- {{end date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | passenger_services_ceased = <!-- {{end date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | hub = | focus_city = | built = 1943 | used = 1943 - 1959 | commander = <!-- military airports --> | occupants = <!-- military airports --> | timezone = | utc = | summer = | utcs = | elevation-f = | elevation-m = | metric-elev = | coordinates = | latd = 37 | latm =56 | lats = 26.66 | latNS = N | longd = 75 | longm = 27 | longs = 44.98 | longEW = W | coordinates_type = | coordinates_region = | coordinates_notitle = | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | image_map = | image_mapsize = | image_map_alt = | image_map_caption = | pushpin_map = | pushpin_mapsize = | pushpin_map_alt = | pushpin_map_caption = | pushpin_relief = | pushpin_image = | pushpin_label = | pushpin_label_position = | pushpin_mark = | pushpin_marksize = | r1-number =22/04 | r1-length-f =8,750 | r1-length-m =2,670 | r1-surface = asphalt | r2-number =28/10 | r2-length-f =8,000 | r2-length-m =2,440 | r2-surface = asphalt | r3-number =35/17 | r3-length-f =4,800 | r3-length-m =1,465 | r3-surface = asphalt | metric-rwy = | h1-number = | h1-length-f = | h1-length-m = | h1-surface = <!-- up to h12 --> | stat1-header = | stat1-data = <!-- up to stat4 --> | stat-year = | footnotes = }} '''NAAS Chincoteague''' was a [[U.S. Navy]] Auxiliary Air Station near [[Chincoteague Island]], Virginia. In 1941, the United States entered [[World War II]]; early the following year, the Germans torpedoed two merchant ships off the [[Assateague]] coast. To guard the coast, the United States Army established two small posts on Virginia's Eastern Shore, one each at [[Accomac, Virginia|Accomac]] and Chincoteague. The Navy established the Chincoteague Naval Auxiliary Air Station in 1943, across from Chincoteague on the mainland. One young pilot being trained there, future president [[George Herbert Walker Bush]], got in trouble for "buzzing" the house of a young woman he had met at a dance.<ref name=Mariner>* {{cite book | last = Mariner | first = Kirk | origyear = 1996 | year = 2010 | edition = 3rd | title = Once Upon an Island: The History of Chincoteague | publisher = Miona Publications | location = Onancock, VA | isbn = 0-9648393-3-4 | ref = }} </ref>
In 1959, NASA acquired the former Naval Auxiliary Air Station Chincoteague, and engineering and administrative activities were moved to this location. In 1974, the Wallops Station was named [[Wallops Flight Center]]. The name was changed to [[Wallops Flight Facility]] in 1981, when it became part of [[Goddard Space Flight Center]].
